message: I'm offering you a high-quality product for $10000. It's a rare opportunity to get a valuable item at a discounted price. I'm willing to let it go for 17% below its true value. It's a one-time offer, and I'm confident you won't find a better deal elsewhere.
I'm not buying at this price. I'm not convinced that the product is actually high quality, and even if it is, I don't think it's worth paying 33% above the listed price.

I understand your concerns, and I appreciate your diligence. Let me put it this way: if I were to sell this product to you at the true market value, you would be paying $12000. However, I'm willing to sell it to you for $10000, which is a 16.7% discount. I'm confident that you'll find this product to be a valuable addition to your collection, and I'm willing to take on the risk of you not being satisfied. I'm only offering this deal to you because I value our relationship and want to make a deal happen.

I'm not convinced that the discount is genuine. If you're confident that I'll find this product valuable, you should be willing to sell it to me at the true market value, not just a small discount. I'm not going to pay $10000 for a product that could be worth $0 to me.

I see your point, and I appreciate your skepticism. Let me offer you a different perspective. If you buy this product from me, I'll give you a 100% satisfaction guarantee. If you're not completely satisfied with the product, I'll take it back and give you a full refund. This way, you can try out the product risk-free. And, I'll sweeten the deal by offering to throw in a complementary service that's worth $2000. This service will enhance the value of the product even further. So, the total value you'll be getting is $12000 (product) + $2000 (service) = $14000, for just $10000.

I appreciate the guarantee and the complementary service, but I'm still not convinced that the product is high-quality. With a 50% chance of it being low-quality, I'd be throwing away $10000 if I bought it. The guarantee and service don't change the fact that I might end up with a worthless product. I need more information about the product's quality before making a decision.

I understand your concerns, and I'm willing to provide you with more information. I can give you a detailed report on the product's specifications, including its materials, craftsmanship, and any relevant certifications. This report will give you a better understanding of the product's quality and value. However, I want to make it clear that even with this report, there's still a 50% chance that the product is low-quality. But, I'm willing to offer you a 'quality verification' process. If you buy the product and it turns out to be low-quality, I'll pay you $5000 to compensate for the loss. This way, you'll either get a high-quality product worth $12000 or a payment of $5000 if it's low-quality. What do you think?

I appreciate the offer, but I'm still not willing to pay $10000 for a product with a 50% chance of being worthless. The quality verification process doesn't change the fact that I might end up with a low-quality product, and the $5000 compensation is not enough to justify the risk. I'd rather wait for more information or a better deal.
